messageBody:
> > I would like to invoke my unit test from ant and include java style
> > properties that are accesible from the Junit test code. For example, the
> > file test_case1.properties includes:
>
> take a look at the PropertyManager and XMLPropertyManager classes of the
> Junit-addons library: <http://junit-addons.sf.net>.

Vladimir (the other one ;-) ) wanted to know the advantages of the
PropertyManager over the default system properties. Since this is
likely to interest other users, I reply on the ml.

- when you have more than a few properties, managing them is a nightmare
(that's why I wrote the PropertyManager class)

- if you are running the same tests from different environments (in an
IDE via a JUnit task, in an Ant script via the JUnit target...) and
using the system properties, you have to modify every call of the JUnit
runner (in your IDE, in your build script...) each time you (or another
developer) add or modify a property.

- [if you are using a build script] normally several developers are
working with the same build.xml file but with different properties
(username/password, location of the servers...). Defining the
"variable" information (the properties) into the "static" file (the
build script) is IMO not the right thing to do

- junit-addons gets some more downloads :-)

Does anyone have other good reasons?

-Vladimir
